title: Brihadishvara Temple
summary: The Brihadishvara Temple, also known as Rajarajesvaram, is a magnificent Shaivite Hindu temple in Thanjavur, Tamil Nadu, India. Built by Chola emperor Rajaraja I between 1003 and 1010 CE, it stands as a prime example of Dravidian architecture, particularly the Chola style. This granite temple features one of South India's tallest vimana towers, a massive Shiva lingam, and exquisite sculptures, including the commissioned brass Nataraja. Part of the UNESCO "Great Living Chola Temples" World Heritage Site, it remains a significant place of worship and a major tourist attraction, despite historical damage and later additions like fortified walls.

current_status: The Brihadishvara Temple is a well-preserved ancient Hindu temple standing amidst fortified walls added after the 16th century. It is one of the largest Hindu temples and a vital component of the UNESCO World Heritage Site "Great Living Chola Temples." Despite some missing artwork due to historical damage, it continues to function as a significant place of worship and is a highly visited tourist attraction in Tamil Nadu.
future_prospects: The temple is expected to continue its role as a major pilgrimage site and a prime destination for cultural tourism. Ongoing efforts will likely focus on its preservation as a UNESCO World Heritage Site, maintaining its structural integrity and artistic treasures. It will remain a crucial subject for historical, architectural, and religious studies, serving as a testament to the achievements of the Chola dynasty and Dravidian art.
